page.title: 02The Ecology of Bramdean
page.content: Area has an equable climate, generally mild winters and fairly warm if not always dry summers. Underlying rock formations are cretaceous with some upper layers of clay with flints. There are several areas of deciduous woodlands where oaks and beech predominate, but small coniferous plantations are becoming more prevalent. Flowers are generally of calcerous loving species typical of which are knapweed, scabious, marjoram, St.John's wort, harebells and cowslips. Of rarer butterflies purple emperor, white admiral, brown argus, and marbled white, are present but no fritillaries. Of larger mammals roe deer, foxes, badgers, hares, rabbits and squirrels are known. Shutts Copse, a hazel coppice, is actively managed by the Hampshire and Isle of Wight Naturalists Trust.
